posts.name: Özgür Soysal
posts.cooked: Is it possible for two robots to communicate with each other through their radios in match? If possible, what are the ways?

posts.name: Mark McLeod
posts.cooked: No. Robots are isolated from one another.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked:
The short answer is no. Each robot is on its own isolated network and can’t directly talk to other robots. For more information, see the FMS Whitepaper .

Theoretically, there’s nothing in the rules preventing robots from somehow relaying information to one another, but it would be difficult to coordinate it and you would need to avoid breaking R706 and E301 .

posts.cooked: I am not that familiar with the driver station setup or the framework the robots communicate with the FMS , but I think it may be possible to connect the corresponding driver stations to each other with ethernet so that neither of the rules are violated while also channeling all robot communication through the ARENA. What are your thoughts?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
Maybe you could use IR, since it’s technically just light? It would be susceptible to interference, but you could probably transmit rudimentary signals between robots using it (much like how a TV remote works).

Likewise, any sort of visual communication that doesn’t interfere with other teams vision would probably also be allowed, and with recent advancements to machine vision, may eventually become practical.

As for this:

thewizardofoz:

I am not that familiar with the driver station setup or the framework the robots communicate with the FMS , but I think it may be possible to connect the corresponding driver stations to each other with ethernet so that neither of the rules are violated while also channeling all robot communication through the ARENA. What are your thoughts?

I would think this would not be permitted, it would technically be in violation of the driver station size rule, and even aside from that I think any ref or FTA looking at it would be extremely skeptical about it violating robot communication rules. They don’t ever want there to be a situation where one teams DS controls another teams robot, even if all teams involved agree to it.

posts.name: Özgür Soysal
posts.cooked:
Yeah, IR is always a possibility, although I worry that the need to install a custom circuit or COTS component for each of your alliance robots may render IR impractical.

Also, since there aren’t many reflective surfaces around the ARENA, it may need proper testing to see how robust it is against obstacles, which would be hard unless you have a one-to-one replica of the field and the venue.

Maybe strong IR sources and sensitive photodiodes would work to get rid of this dependence? IR also has the problem of being easily jammed, and it is virtually impossible to locate the “jammer” although it is against competition rules to intentionally jam opponent robot communication.

Actually due to the ambiguity in R706 (what does “signal” mean in this context), there are no regulations against communicating with ultrasound (probably with ASK modulation), or any other method of information exchange. Does the FRC robot create unnecessary noise in the ultrasound region?

Unfortunately, ultrasound has the problem of easily getting obstructed by the field elements due to its small wavelength.

Does any other method come to your mind?

posts.name: Rick Sisk - Mentor 8888, Coach FLL 26
posts.cooked: How about using LED lights on one robot to signal to another robot’s vision system?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
thewizardofoz:

Does any other method come to your mind?

An extra monitor on the robot or DS that generates QR codes (or similar) that robot vision can read (but that doesn’t interfere with standard Apriltags). There is precedent for this last year, since some teams had their own custom tags (in a different family) on the loading stations). If you could quickly convert the data you were trying to transmit to QR and had code other teams could read it with, it might be plausible.

We kind of did something like this a few years ago. We had extra weight so we had a pair of 7" screens mounted to the robot controlled by a RasPi that took DIO binary inputs from the RoboRIO and played different memes on the screens depending on what the robot was doing at the time. It was just for fun, but you could use the same method with vision for robot-to-robot coms too, though it would require line of sight.

posts.name: Özgür Soysal
posts.cooked: Yeah, that is also a possibility. You could implement some encryption though, both at the transmitter and receiver side to cope with other sources and malicious actors. Also you may need some forward error correction scheme or ARQ to resend when an acknowledge flag is not received.

Yeah, that is also a possibility though using vision requires a constant line of sight  between the robots, and that scares me.

The idea of generating QR codes on the driver station to relay information is very promising if you already face your camera towards your DS throughout the match.

You can use some semantic goal filtering in the state space of the robots so that you only need to communicate the actions you want the robot to take, greatly reducing the required data rate of the channel.

This method is in fact quite promising. Do you see any additions or corrections and/or any other method that may outcompete the above approach?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
thewizardofoz:

This method is in fact quite promising. Do you see any additions or corrections and/or any other method that may outcompete the above approach?

Within the current communication rules, not really. Pretty much anything legal would have to operate in the optical spectrum to avoid the wireless restrictions (even that is technically a bit questionable, depending on how you interpret the rules), and anything on the optical spectrum is going to encounter issues with LoS and interference, not to mention bandwidth limitations (short of doing something crazy like actively targeted laser communication).

Technically using an ultrasonic method could be legal and, theoretically, less LoS-dependant, but the range is severely limited and it’s even more susceptible to noise interference, which makes it impractical.

I’ve played around with the idea of having some kind of standard robot identification method that teams could use (like mounting some sort of “tag” above their swerve modules to denote their robots dimensions) to see where other bots are on the field for autonomous pathfinding and such, but currently such a system would be optional (you’d have to convince teams to use it) and would have a number of design constraints on the robot itself in order to work.

I’m curious what your end-goal is with this? Or is this just a thought exercise?

EDIT: One other thought I did have is, depending on the field (this year’s field would be a bit tricky because of how the speaker sits between driver stations) you could use your optical communication method of choice to communicate directly between Driver Stations, rather than between robots. Since the DSs (hopefully) don’t move during a match, you wouldn’t have any drops in your “coms” due to LoS, though it would require other teams to build compatible DSs.

I’ve played around with the idea of having some kind of standard robot identification method that teams could use (like mounting some sort of “tag” above their swerve modules to denote their robots dimensions) to see where other bots are on the field for autonomous pathfinding and such, but currently such a system would be optional (you’d have to convince teams to use it) and would have a number of design constraints on the robot itself in order to work.

I’m curious what your end-goal is with this? Or is this just a thought exercise?

I’ve been thinking about how we would be able to improve the game strategy dynamically if we had a communication channel between robots for some time, but the main motivation was the research I nowadays do at college where we do semantic signal processing and next-state prediction to optimize an agent’s path (decision making robot) towards its goal. You can perform some graph based filtering to compress the required transmission packet size drastically (~100,000 times)

This paper summarizes the core idea in mind: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2109.11885.pdf

So essentially you can have the ability to train robots in a playground and dynamically change game strategy based on the actions of your opponents and any other chance based elements of the game.

Additionally, robot to robot communication maybe would achieve other objectives which may expand onto other branches.

So half of the motivation is just curiosity, and the other half is some experimental ideas.

Al_Skierkiewicz:

R707

The blue box on R707 would seem to allow optical communication using Cameras, and IR/LED signaling appears to be permitted as long as it’s not receiving commands that are “human originated”…

“Devices that employ signals in the visual spectrum (e.g. cameras) and non-RF sensors that don’t receive human-originated commands (e.g. “beam break” sensors or IR sensors on the ROBOT used to detect FIELD elements) are not wireless communication devices and thus this rule doesn’t apply.”
